ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to write screenplays in proper format, read screenplays, and write film critiques. I also learned how to tell whole stories in a short amount of pages, as well as write more realistic dialogue.
Great

I developed a lot of insights into script formatting, script coverage (really useful for assimilating the formatting exercises from class), how to craft believable dialogue, all of the necessary background work needed to create three-dimensional characters, and the terse, action-driven nature of writing scripts themselves.
How to write a short screenplay at a professional level. Also, what a script treatment is and how to get jobs in the industry.
How to properly write and analyze screenplays asan industry standard
Screenwriting basics, final draft, story structure, dialogue writing!

I improved my storytelling abilities through screenwriting and also gained a firm grasp on screenwritings formatting conventions. I also learned how to write script coverage, which has been super helpful in applying to script development internships in the film industry!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor Lapadula does a great job of keeping everyone engaged. He really wants everyone to be successful, and proves it by supporting and inviting his past students. Sometimes activities felt very rushed because of the size of the class and the limited time we had together.
High

I think that this is a fantastic course that really meshes well with any type of student, be they serious potential screenwriters or people looking to dip their toes into what it is like to screenwrite or work in the creative department of a movie studio. You really get out of it what you put into it. The main strength is Professor Lapadula himself: he is funny, knowledgeable, and always willing to help. The class is organized really well. The midterm folder is a lot, but that's only if you leave it to the last possible moments (not recommended; if possible, chip at it gradually throughout the first half of the semester - your spring break self will be thanking you profusely).

The strengths are that this is a really fun class for anyone who is seriously interested in writing a screenplay! A weakness is that it could have been better organized with set due dates from the beginning of the semester.

Considering that it is a beginners course it is understandable that the primary focus was getting all of the technicalities of screenwriting correct, I wished that there was more of a focus on developing a good story but I know that will be the focus of the intermediate class.

The course is a wonderful introduction to the world of screenwriting -- however, it mostly teaches you the technical aspects of screenwriting. I wished we would have gotten into story structure and how to develop characters more. For the midterm folder, we had to write coverage, but we never really went over exactly how to write good coverage. However, I really liked the dialogue writing workshop!

Something you usually dont see on course reviews, but I wish there were more assignments! I enjoyed only having my own screenplay to work on for the last half of the course, but I would have appreciated having more writing exercises to help me keep writing things other than just my screenplay.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely, if you're interested in screenwriting. The final project is the screenplay you've been working towards all semester, so it's nice to leave the course with your own written short film. Be sure to start the midterm folder early, otherwise it will take up a chunk of your spring break...
Yes

Yes, I would, especially if you have an interest in film or any type of creative writing. It really makes you appreciate how much work goes into crafting a story, and is challenging yet rewarding in its own right.
Absolutely, writing screenplays is one of my favorite pastimes and hobbies, and to meet many other students with the same passions is such a relief.
Yes! It's a good way to dip your toes into screenwriting!

Definitely! If youre interested in storytelling and would like to learn how to do so in a screenplay format, this is the course for you. There is definitely room for a range of skill levels in this course as well, so if youre fairly new to creative writing, I wouldnt be daunted by it.
